review.title: Using graph transformation algorithms to generate natural language equivalents of icons expressing medical concepts
review.abstract: A graphical language addresses the need to communicate medical information in a synthetic way. Medical concepts are expressed by icons conveying fast visual information about patients' current state or about the known effects of drugs. In order to increase the visual language's acceptance and usability, a natural language generation interface is currently developed. In this context, this paper describes the use of an informatics method ---graph transformation--- to prepare data consisting of concepts in an OWL-DL ontology for use in a natural language generation component. The OWL concept may be considered as a star-shaped graph with a central node. The method transforms it into a graph representing the deep semantic structure of a natural language phrase. This work may be of future use in other contexts where ontology concepts have to be mapped to half-formalized natural language expressions.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This work takes place in the field of the visualization of medical knowledge. It is part of an ongoing project that aims to develop and promote new interfaces for accessing medical information systems, including a graphical representation language, VCM [1], where medical concepts are expressed through icons, and a multilingual user interface. Graphical language is used to provide complex information in a form adapted to synthetic visual perception. To be accepted and used more widely within different medical information systems, icons must be as easy to learn and use as possible. From this point of view, it is necessary to provide users with easily accessible natural expressions of meaning conveyed by each icon, e.g. in the form of a pop-up balloon that appears when the mouse cursor hovers over the icons. Icons express meanings that arise from the combination of a finite set of elementary meaning components.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Perspective
sections.text: The next step in the present work is the development of a complete text generation module, based on the generation of phrase structure trees by deriving elementary trees in a lexicalized TAG grammar [11]. Graphic language is based on minimal expression segments, the so-called icons, the description of which is given above (section 2). These icons can be combined according to a limited visual syntax to compose more complex iconic expressions: on bidimensional surfaces structured in predefined fields, they form synthetic visualization grids that display information about the complete set of contraindications or side effects of a drug or the clinical condition of a patient. A future expansion of work on natural language generation will take into account that the visual syntax, in order to be able to translate complex graphic expressions into texts in the chosen natural target language, can translate more complex graphic expressions into texts.

referenceMentions.context: It is part of an ongoing project aiming at developing and promoting the use of new interfaces for accessing medical information systems, including a graphical representation language, VCM [1], whereby medical concepts are expressed by icons, and a multi-lingual interface.
The graphical language VCM is built against an ontology of medical concepts, defined with the OWL-DL representation formalism [2].

This problem has already raised interest in the semantic web community [3], and has given way to approaches allowing to precisely verbalize the set of logical restrictions and specifications which define concepts in a logical description language like OWLDL [4].

This problem has already raised interest in the semantic web community [3], and has given way to approaches allowing to precisely verbalize the set of logical restrictions and specifications which define concepts in a logical description language like OWLDL [4].
In the medical field, work has been done towards automatic generation of case descriptions in natural language from an RDF input [5].

Natural language generation takes as input data something that should be close to a deep semantic representation of some natural language fragment, that is a semantic graph (we will avoid the use of the term “conceptual graph” coined by John Sowa [6], since it has a more specific formal definition; moreover, it may mislead the reader into confusing “concepts” of conceptual graphs with “concepts” of OWL-DL).

There are many reasons for this: first, there are different medical terminologies, and our visual language must be able to be used in conjunction with any of them; second, the ontology approach, with a few discrete atomic axes, permits to express a much greater number of possible combinations of medical concepts than the terminology approach, which sets in advance a finite set of possibilities (this rationale also is behind the GRAIL language, defined within the GALEN project [7]).
The approach adopted here is based on the principle of “graph grammars” [8], which has given way to important developments in the past two decades, especially in the field of process modelling [9].
The approach adopted here is based on the principle of “graph grammars” [8], which has given way to important developments in the past two decades, especially in the field of process modelling [9].

Our algorithm may be classified in the category of graph grammars proper, not simply graph-rewriting systems (following the distinction drawn by Blostein [10]), because it makes a difference between terminal graphs and non-terminal graphs, analogous to the similar difference that phrase-structure grammars (PSG) make between terminal strings (made up of terminal symbols only) and nonterminal strings in a linear language.

The next step in the present work is the development of a complete text generation module, based on the generation of phrase structure trees by derivation of elementary trees in a TAG lexicalized grammar [11].
